questions.question_text:
A field exists in search results, but isn't being displayed in the fields sidebar.
How can it be added to the fields sidebar?

choices.D: This scenario isn't possible because all fields returned from a search always appear in the fields sidebar.
choices.C: Click Selected Fields and select the field to add it to Interesting Fields.
choices.A: Click All Fields and select the field to add it to Selected Fields.
choices.B: Click Interesting Fields and select the field to add it to Selected Fields.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A is correct
The answer is A

Selected Answer: A
It's A when it is not showing at all. The question isn't about Interesting Fields or Selected Fields, it's about making it visible if it's hidden.

Selected Answer: A
A is right

to add fields to the selected fields list, click all fields at the top of the fields sidebar
Reference: https://docs.splunk.com/Documentation/Splunk/9.0.0/SearchTutorial/Usefieldstosearch
A is right. You cannot click "Interesting Fields", however you can click "All FIelds" and select field.
A is correct

Selected Answer: B
Is not B?

A is correct
PAG 82
Ans : B

Top line explaining Forwarders.
" Forwarders require minimal resources and have little impact on performance, so they can usually reside on the machines where the data originates. "

questions.question_text: Which of the following Splunk components typically resides on the machines where data originates?

discussion.content: The answer is C, a is alpha-numeric whereas # is just numeric

Selected Answer: C
The character that typically denotes alphanumeric field values is C. a. 
Letter 'a' is used to represent alphanumeric values
C is Correct

comments.content:
Incorrect!

a indicates the field values are alphanumeric
# indicates the values are numeric
Page 77 of Splunk fundamentals 1

You can also read more about how it categories the fields into these two categories here: https://community.splunk.com/t5/Splunk-Search/Field-categorization/m-p/87018

discussion.content:
a = string
# = numeric
% = alphanumeric So answer is B
It's C, pdf 79
The answer is D. If you look at the interesting and Selected fields, you will see these symbols: #a
Has anyone seen % as the answer?

questions.question_text: What is the main requirement for creating visualizations using the Splunk UI?

choices.D: Your search must transform event data into JSON formatted data first.
choices.C: Your search must transform event data into statistical data tables first.
choices.A: Your search must transform event data into Excel file format first.
choices.B: Your search must transform event data into XML formatted data first.

discussion.content: B is Correct

questions.question_text: What syntax is used to link key/value pairs in search strings?
